title: Eustachy Erazm Sanguszko
text:
Prince Eustachy Erazm Sanguszko (1768–1844) was a Polish <a href="Szlachta">nobleman</a>, general, military commander, diplomat and politician.
Early life.
Eustachy Erazm Sanguszko was born in 1768 to <a href="Hieronim%20Janusz%20Sanguszko">Hieronim Janusz Sanguszko</a> and <a href="Cecylia%20Usrzula%20Potocka">Cecylia Usrzula Potocka</a>.
French Royal army.
In the years 1780–1786, Sanguszko graduated from the military school of <a href="Strasbourg">Strasbourg</a> and served in the <a href="R%C3%A9giment%20Royal-Allemand">Régiment Royal-Allemand</a> (together with <a href="Stanis%C5%82aw%20Mokronowski">Stanisław Mokronowski</a>) of the <a href="French%20Royal%20Army%20%281652%E2%80%931830%29">French Royal army</a>.
Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth.
Four-Year Sejm.
On 3 February 1789, Sanguszko began service in the <a href="Crown%20of%20the%20Kingdom%20of%20Poland">Crown</a> Army as a <a href="captain">captain</a> in the . On 5 October 1789, he was promoted to <a href="major">major</a>, and on 28 April 1792, to vice-brigadier. He was a representative of the <a href="Lublin%20Voivodeship%20%281474%E2%80%931795%29">Lublin Voivodeship</a> in the <a href="Great%20Sejm">Great Sejm</a> of 1788–1792. Sanguszko partook in the <a href="Polish%E2%80%93Russian%20War%20of%201792">War of the Second Partition</a> where he fought at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Ziele%C5%84ce">Battle of Zieleńce</a> as a cavalry brigadier, receiving the <a href="Virtuti%20Militari">Virtuti Militari</a> in its wake on June 23. On 29 July 1792, the 24-year-old Sanguszko was promoted to <a href="brigadier">brigadier</a>, having taken over the command of the whole brigade on June 25. As the <a href="Targowica%20Confederation">Targowica Confederation</a> had won, he joined the <a href="Imperial%20Russian%20Army">Imperial Russian Army</a> to save his goods and possessions from confiscation.
Kościuszko Uprising.
During the <a href="Ko%C5%9Bciuszko%20Uprising">Kościuszko Uprising</a> in 1794 he was a major general and a divisional commander. At the <a href="Battle%20of%20Szczekociny">Battle of Szczekociny</a> he saved Kościuszko's life. Then during the siege of <a href="Warsaw">Warsaw</a> he was wounded.
Napoleonic Wars.
He was a member of the general staff of <a href="Napoleon%20Bonaparte">Napoleon Bonaparte</a> during the Russian campaign (with the rank of brigadier general) and took part in the march on Moscow. In the <a href="Duchy%20of%20Warsaw">Duchy of Warsaw</a> he was the <a href="Regimentarz">vice-Regimentarz</a> of the <a href="pospolite%20ruszenie">pospolite ruszenie</a> (general call-up).
To protect family land holdings in <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>, Sanguszko refused to participate in Prince <a href="J%C3%B3zef%20Poniatowski">Poniatowski's</a> <a href="German%20Campaign%20of%201813">1813 campaign</a>, for which the commander-in-chief, an old friend, punished him harshly with a dishonourable discharge from the army.
Congress of Poland.
After the fall of Napoleon, Sanguszko settled on his ancestral lands that included the battlefield of <a href="Battle%20of%20Ziele%C5%84ce">Zieleńce</a>. There he often pondered on past historic events in which he took part and described his thoughts in his "Memoirs". Between 1817–1820 he was the governor marshal of <a href="Volhynia">Volhynia</a>.
Personal life.
Family.
On June 26, 1798 in <a href="Slavuta">Slavuta</a>, he married <a href="Klementyna%20Czartoryska">Klementyna Czartoryska</a> with whom he had three children: Dorota (1799-1831), <a href="Roman%20Sanguszko">Roman</a> (1800-81), and <a href="W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw%20Hieronim%20Sanguszko">Władysław</a> (1803–70). Earlier on he had been romantically involved with <a href="Julia%20Lubomirska">Julia Lubomirska</a>.
Honours.
He was decorated with the <a href="Knight%27s%20Cross">Knight's Cross</a> of the Polish Virtuti Militari and Chevalier of the French <a href="Legion%20of%20Honour">Legion of Honour</a>.
